Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Aerosol Concentrations, Sources and Transport Pathways within the Arctic Polar Dome during Recent Millennia
Award.AbstractNarration: The role of aerosols in climate forcing is significant but poorly understood. The primary goals of this project are to (1) develop unique high-time-resolution, millennial-scale records of biomass burning, dust, volcanic, industrial pollution, and sea salt aerosols for two ice core sites inside the Arctic polar dome and (2) use new and leveraged general circulation models (GCM) and other modeling to interpret these and similar ice core records from outside the polar dome to better understand source regions and transport pathways of aerosols to different regions of the Arctic and their climatic and environmental impacts. Measurements of >35 elemental and chemical components of these aerosols will be made at high depth resolution (>50 measurements per year) in archived ice cores from two lower elevation sites on opposite sides of the Arctic: a 430 m core collected by the University of Copenhagen in 2006 from Flade Isblink ice cap in far northeastern Greenland and a 724 m core collected by the Alfred Wegener Institute (AWI) in 1999 to 2001 from Akademii Nauk ice cap in the Russian Arctic. The measurements build on recently published findings from similar analyses in shallower ice cores. Flade Isblink will provide a >3500 year record of aerosols in the lower troposphere in the North Atlantic sector of the Arctic Ocean ? a region particularly sensitive to changes in Arctic sea ice ? while Akademii Nauk will provide a > 3000 year record of past aerosols in northern Eurasia, as well as dust and pollutants from eastern Asia. By extending instrumental records to recent centuries and millennia, this new generation of ice core records, coupled with model simulations, will transform understanding of recent and late Holocene changes in hemispheric atmospheric circulation, aerosol transport across the polar front, and feedbacks between climate and aerosols.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this project was to investigate temporal and spatial variations in dust, biomass burning, volcanic, pollution, and other aerosols in the Arctic. Aerosols are small droplets or particles in the air and in precipitation. Ice-core aerosol records reflect past emissions, atmospheric concentrations, and atmospheric transport pathways and so are important for evaluation and parameterization of Earth system and other models. However, aerosols also directly and indirectly impact radiative forcing, heavy metal and acid pollution, snow melt processes, nutrient fertilization, etc. so understanding past, present, and future changes in aerosol sources and deposition is important for climate prediction and policy making.

Specifically, the goal was to develop the first detailed ice-core records of aerosol inside the Arctic polar dome and compare and contrast these with existing similar records from high elevation sites outside the polar dome. The Arctic polar dome is a large region of the atmosphere over the Arctic basin characterized by restricted airflow near the surface and limited exchange with the larger atmosphere, so historical aerosol records may be very different inside and outside of the polar dome. Low elevation sites are relatively warm even in the high-latitude Arctic so reliable chemical measurements are challenging and accurate interpretation illusive because water from melting of surface snow percolates into the snowpack, redistributing mass and chemical impurities and making dating of the ice core records particularly problematic.

Using the unique Desert Research Institute (DRI) continuous ice-core analytical system, a broad range of elements and chemical species were measured in two archived ice cores previously collected by European researchers from low elevation sites within the Arctic polar dome: (1) the 724 m Akademii Nauk (AN) ice core collected in the late 1990s from the Russian Arctic as part of a German/Russian collaboration and (2) the 430 m Flade Isblink (FlIs) collected in 2006 by the Danes from a coastal ice cap in far northeastern Greenland. At ~600 m elevation and north of 80oN latitude, both sites are well within the Arctic polar dome.

As expected, extensive surface melting and percolation made dating of the ice-core records difficult, particularly in the deeper sections of the AN core. While efforts to refine the chronologies continue and are accomplished largely through cross-dating and synchronization with similar ice core aerosol records from readily dated higher elevation sites as they become available, it is clear that reliable records of aerosol concentration and deposition were obtained from both ice cores. The aerosol records extend to AD ~750 in the FLIs core and at least to BC 1000 in the AN core. Comparisons both between these two cores as well as to high elevation cores from the DRI Arctic aerosol array are ongoing but show surprising similarities as well as substantial differences. For example, while the important climate forcer black carbon peaked at most high elevation sites in the early 20th C and declined substantially by the mid-20th C as a result of more efficient burning technologies and a shift to oil and gas from coal in North America and western Europe, concentrations and fluxes in the AN core peaked in the 1980s, apparently reflecting Soviet-era industrial emissions in northern Eurasia. Heavy metal and other pollution aerosols follow similar patterns. Conversely, the FlIs record shares similarities both with the high elevation sites and the AN site. From these and other comparisons, it is clear that the histories of aerosols inside and outside the polar dome were different and that aerosol histories within the polar dome reflected different emission sources.
